name: pineapple production | pineapple | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8560/documentation

This dataset represents pineapple production.;;Yield: 86 t / ha.;Duration of one cropping cycle: 24 months.;Field production.;The LCA study, from which this LCI has been derived, contains detailed descriptions of the system boundaries and the data sources used (Stoessel et al. 2012). The publication is published and freely available with comprehensive supporting information:;http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577;Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.;;This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

From maintenance of the orchards after harvest of the previous crop.


This activity ends with harvest and storage. 
The dataset includes a storage period of 0.6 month and it's use of electricity.  And for the production, mulch films are included and disposed according to the disposal techniques used in the production country. The pesticide inputs are classified according to their chemical classes and the emmssions are assigned to the soil (100%). Mercury emissions are neglected due to a lack of data while other heavy metal emissions are included. The dataset doesn't include infrastructure for production and storage facilities. No transports for agricultural means of production from the regional storage to the farm are included.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/012:Growing of perennial crops/0122:Growing of tropical and subtropical fruits

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Production without production standard, but according to GAP
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The dataset is extrapolated to global production.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The LCI is based on pineapple production information from different sources (peer reviewed journals, books, extension leaflets, personal information) and is well representative for a conventional production in their main production countries. Most probably it is representative for productions in other countries or farms which produces similarly. 
Please refer to Stoessel et al. (2012) for more information: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/es2030577
Franziska Stoessel, Ronnie Juraske, Stephan Pfister, Stefanie Hellweg. (2012) Life Cycle Inventory and Carbon and Water FoodPrint of Fruits and Vegetables: Application to a Swiss Retailer. Environmental Science & Technology 6(46) 3253-3262.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of pineapple is calculated to be circa 2.49E-04 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: 'diphenylether-compound', 'glyphosate', 'organophosphorus-compound, unspecified', 'pesticide, unspecified', 'triazine-compound, unspecified'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 4.97E-04 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature. The gross energy is calculated using following formula; gross energy (MJ) = crude protein (kg)*23.04 (MJ/kg)+crude fat (kg)*38.96 (MJ/kg)+crude fibre (kg)*17.95 (MJ/kg)+carbohydrates (kg)*17.17 (MJ/kg) (formula based on expert opinion, cross referenced; Diepenbrock, 2012, Energy Balance in Crop Production). The product composition of fruits and vegetables is extracted from the USDA National Nutrient Database for Standard Reference (http://ndb.nal.usda.gov/, accessed 20131114). Crude protein (g)= 5.4, crude fat (g)= 1.2, crude fibre (g)= 14, ash (g)= 2.2, water (g)= 860, carbohydrates (g)= 131.2. The gross energy per kg of DM is 19.82MJ. The calculated gross energy per kg of reference product is thus 2.58MJ.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of fertilisers needed for the production of 'pineapple' is calculated to be circa 1.21E-02 kg. Fertiliser/s used in this dataset is/are: 'ammonium nitrate, as N', 'phosphate fertiliser, as P2O5', 'potassium sulfate, as K2O', 'urea, as N'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of fertiliser/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 2.43E-02 kg of packaging for fertilisers is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Global average LUC emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The emission are based on the relative change in production areas in all countries for a given crop. The weighted average is used which takes into acount relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.
